awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Ice Melting Induced by Flows in an Adjacent Immiscible Liquid Layer
awd_abstract_narration:
The deterioration of ice by spill contamination is a complex process that is not well understood. This research project will study the effects of convective flow and melt layer film on the melting dynamics of an ice wall in contact with a heated oil.  Such situations would be encountered during an oil spill event in the Arctic regions when the oil layer absorbs heat from the Sun or from flames if the oil is burning.  The heat absorption will cause different melt patterns and carve out lateral cavities inside the ice wall. At a large scale, this process can cause a shift in the structure and geology of floating ice blocks and thereby impact the Arctic ecosystem in unanticipated ways.  This research project will address this knowledge gap through a series of experiments that use imaging and tracking methods to analyze the ice melting process.  The project researchers will also create project-based learning opportunities for juniors and seniors at the Worcester Polytechnic Institute and a new graduate-level course at the University of Notre Dame.

The research project investigates the fundamental science underlying the interaction of an immiscible liquid with ice.  Previous studies on the melting of sea ice have considered parameters such as salinity and natural convection in the water to understand the fluid dynamics and heat transfer aspects of melting.  However, ice melting by an oil layer is significantly different because of the characteristics of oil that influence the heat transfer pathways substantially. For example, the immiscibility of oil layer with water and presence of the gas-phase brings about interfacial forces that change the fluid flow and heat transfer dynamics. The induced convective patterns in the liquid layer by addition of interfacial forces to the existing buoyancy flows will cause unique flow patterns that impact the ice melting. Therefore, the scientific understanding of fluid flow and heat transfer pathways in the oil layer is required to predict oil-ice interaction and melting rates. Identification of the controlling mechanisms governing the convective flows will be achieved through the novel use of luminescence imaging techniques combined with particle tracking velocimetry. These experimental approaches will give spatiotemporal information on fluid transport and temperature. The knowledge obtained from this study will be pivotal in developing numerical models that address melting phenomena.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In this study, a series of experiments were conducted to investigate the flow created by heating a floating liquid (such as oil on water) adjacent to an ice wall. Figure 1 shows a sketch of the experimental set up. The situation is comparable to an oil spill in the arctic for example. The oil spill can absorb radiation from the sun, and the flow resulting from the temperature gradient between the cold ice and the warm oil creates interesting melting patterns in ice. Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) and University of Notre Dame (UND)  investigated these flows jointly.
Measurements showed that as heat is absorbed by oil a surface flow toward the ice caused by surface-tension (Marangoni) forces is created. With increasing heat absorption,  a recirculation zone is also observed under the free surface and near the ice. The combination of the two flow patterns causes a lateral intrusion in the ice as shown in the Figure 2. A photograph of the melted ice wall is shown in Figure 3. The front view of the lateral cavity shows multiple channels demonstrating the three dimensional nature of the melted ice wall. This implies that the ice is not melting uniformly across its surface, which has important implications for environmental impact assessments and response strategies.
The surface velocity and melting rate for different conditions in shown in Figure 4. The controlling parameters indicated in Figure 4 are heat flux, viscosity, thermal conductivity, surface tension, density, and the thickness of the boundary layer caused by the melted water. 


Last Modified: 11/06/2023
Modified by: Ali S Rangwala

Images (1 of )
  • The flow induced by Marangoni convection in m/s correlates with the rate at which the ice wall melts (mm/min). The controlling parameters are the heat flux, viscosity, surface tension, density, thermal conductivity, and the thickness of the boundary layer created by the melting water.
    Hamed Farahani
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Ali S Rangwala
    Figure 4: Correlation of Surface Velocity and Melt Front Velocity
  • Formation of lateral cavity during melting of ice. The protrusion created in the ice wall deepens with increasing heat flux.
    Hamed Farahani
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Ali S Rangwala
    Figure 2: Influence of Heat Flux
  • The photographs show the lateral cavity formed in the ice. The thickness of the melt layer is also shown. The front view of the lateral cavity cut out shows several channels demonstrating the three dimensional nature of the melting front.
    Hamed Farahani
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Ali S Rangwala
    Figure 3: Lateral Cavity Formation During Ice Melting
  • Illustrative sketch of the experimental setup
    Hamed Farahani
